questions.question: Digital Logic Design is the topic of Chapter 4.
Combinational logic circuits have outputs determined only by the present combination of inputs.
Sequential circuits are a type of combinational logic.
A combinational circuit performs operations specified by a set of Boolean functions.
Decoders and encoders are examples of sequential circuits.
Adder-Subtractor is a topic covered under combinational logic.
Multiplexers are part of sequential logic circuits.
Combinational circuits use memory elements to store previous inputs.
Does a combinational circuit consist of input variables, logic gates, and output variables?
Do logic gates in a combinational circuit generate signals to the outputs based on the inputs?
Are input and output signals in a combinational circuit always analog signals?
Adders are classified as standard components.
Subtractors are not considered standard combinational circuits.
Combinational circuits have memory elements.
The first step in analyzing a combinational circuit is to ensure it is not sequential.
Encoders are not part of standard combinational circuits.
The Boolean functions for each gate output are determined after labeling the gates that are a function of input variables.
You must repeat the process of labeling gates and determining their Boolean functions until the outputs of the circuit are reached.
T1 is defined as A + B + C.
T2 is defined as ABC.
F2 is defined as AB + AC + BC.
T3 is defined as F2’T1.
F1 is defined as T3 + T2.
F1 can be simplified to (A’ + B’C’)(AB’ + AC’ + BC’ + B’C) + ABC.
A’BC’ + A’B’C + AB’C’ + ABC is a Boolean expression.
Labeling the outputs of selected gates with arbitrary symbols is a step in obtaining the truth table from a circuit diagram.
The truth table for the outputs of gates is obtained as a function of the input variables only.
The design of combinational circuits starts from the specification of the problem and results in a logic diagram or a set of Boolean functions.
The first step in designing combinational circuits is to derive the truth table.
The truth table defines the required relationship between inputs and outputs.
Simplification of the output functions can be done using algebraic manipulation.
Computer-based simplification is one of the methods for simplifying output functions.
Propagation of time through the gates is a factor to consider in simplification.
Designing a combinational circuit to check if an input is greater than or equal to a value is mentioned in the text.
Z = 0 when the input is less than 5?
A is the least significant bit?
C is the most significant bit?
Z = 1 for input 101?
Z = 0 for input 111?
The output Z is a single bit?
The input is a 4-bit binary number?
The Boolean expression F=AC+AB represents a logic diagram with AND and OR gates.
A combinational circuit with three inputs and one output will always output 1 if the binary value of the inputs is less than 3.
The binary addition 0 + 0 equals 1.
The binary addition 1 + 0 equals 0.
The Boolean expression F= ∑(5,6,7) represents a sum of minterms.
A combinational circuit that performs addition for two bits is called a half adder.
A combinational circuit that performs addition of three bits is called a half adder.
Two half adders can be combined to create a full adder.
A binary adder-subtractor performs only addition with binary numbers.
A half adder requires two binary inputs and two binary outputs.
The output C in a half adder is given by C = x + y.
The carry output (C) in a full adder is given by the expression C = x + y + z.
A full adder can be used to add three bits: two significant bits and a carry from a previous addition.
In a binary adder, full adders are connected in parallel to sum two binary numbers.
The sum output (S) in a half adder is given by the expression S = x ⊕ y.
The carry output (C) in a half adder is given by the expression C = x + y.
The output carry from each full adder is connected to the input carry of the next full adder in the chain.
A binary subtractor cannot be implemented using a binary adder.
The subtraction of unsigned binary numbers can be done by means of complements.
The input carry C0 must be 0 when performing subtraction.
A - B is calculated as A - B if A >= B.
The 2's complement of (B - A) is used when A < B.
The same circuit can be used for signed numbers if there is no overflow.
A binary subtractor cannot be combined with an adder.
An exclusive-OR gate is included with each full adder to combine addition and subtraction operations.
Overflow occurs when two numbers of n digits each are added and the sum occupies n + 1 digits.
In digital computers, we are not limited by size when performing arithmetic operations.
The detection of an overflow after the addition of two binary numbers depends on whether the numbers are considered to be signed or unsigned.
When two unsigned numbers are added, an overflow is detected from the end carry out of the most significant position.
When two signed numbers are added, the leftmost bit always represents the sign and negative numbers are in 2’s complement form.
When two signed numbers are added, the end carry indicates an overflow.
A decoder converts binary information from n input lines to a maximum of 2n unique output lines.
A decoder always has exactly 2n outputs, regardless of unused combinations.
A 3-to-8 line decoder has 3 input lines and 8 output lines.
A decoder can be used with external OR gates to form logical sums.
Any combinational circuit can be represented by a decoder alone without additional logic gates.
A circuit with n inputs and m outputs can be implemented by a n-to-2n-line decoder and m OR gates.
A full adder has only one output.
The sum output of a full adder is given by S(x, y, z) = (1, 2, 4, 7).
The carry output of a full adder is given by C(x, y, z) = (3, 5, 6, 7).
An encoder performs the same operation as a decoder.
An encoder has 2n (or fewer) input lines and n output lines.
The output lines of an encoder generate the binary code corresponding to the input value.
A 4-to-2 encoder has 4 input lines and 2 output lines.
The encoder has four inputs Y3, Y2, Y1, and Y0.
The encoder has three outputs A1 and A0.
At any time, only one of the four inputs can be '1' to get the respective binary code at the output.
A multiplexer selects binary information from one of many input lines and directs it to multiple output lines.
The selection of a particular input line in a multiplexer is controlled by a set of selection lines.
A set of selection lines determines which input is selected in a MUX.
There are normally 2n input lines and n selection lines in a MUX.
A 4-to-1 MUX has 4 selection lines.
The number of selection lines in a MUX is equal to the number of input lines.
